RT @jburnmurdoch: NEW: the collapse of emergency healthcare in England may be costing 500 lives every week, a close match for non-Covid exc‚Ä¶

@artsyhonker I think "traffic jams" in this metaphor would correspond to blackouts / running out of power. That's not an issue we've really had in the past several years, rather the reverse: e.g. wind farms have been told to stop supplying power because it was overloading the grid.

@artsyhonker If companies needed more energy we'd build more - the government only allows a certain amount of generative power to be added to the grid each year, because there isn't actually much demand for extra power, and presumably they don't want to produce more than we will use.

@artsyhonker I don't think that will be a factor unless it's a lot cheaper than it has been in the past. Until recently, companies could choose to use a lot more energy with little extra financial penalty, they just didn't - we're nowhere near full generation capacity.

@NicUalraig @stuart_macrae @stephendeazley Usually I'd put a single consonant at the start of the syllable - so "fidelis" as "fi-de-lis" - and double consonants split across syllables, "in-ter", "om-nes", "nul-la". No idea if that's ideal but it produces readable underlay and nobody's ever complained!

@NicUalraig @stuart_macrae @stephendeazley Plenty of guides in English but I don't know of a specific one in Latin, I kind of do it by instinct...? All the English ones basically say "hyphenate the way the dictionary does" - so I would recommend getting a cheap Latin dictionary to work from! Happy to proofread etc.

"The Rules" is quite an angry piece but would be ideal for any choir campaigning about climate change; probably better for more mature choirs, teenagers and upwards. Flexible 2-part choir and piano. https://t.co/XXwCayJn12

I'd also like to show you a couple of #ChoirsForClimate pieces which are Creative Commons, for flexible 2-part choir and piano. "Why We Sing" would fit in any concert and is suitable for choirs aged 7+: https://t.co/XpPUbzAUUT Verse 3 can be rewritten to suit your concert theme.

Anything without a recording/video online is also available for free if you're willing to make a recording! E.g. this rather nice SATB (no divisi) anthem which I wrote last month: https://t.co/BdCBEtqiMZ

You can see PDF scores, listen to recordings, and in many cases watch videos with the score. My #ChoirsForClimate and #ChoirsAgainstRacism pieces are released under Creative Commons licenses and can be downloaded for free (donations to good causes appreciated).

@nicomuhly But an amateur playing B will almost certainly make the E quieter than the D#, because their thumb is constrained by the index finger being right next to it.

@nicomuhly They're different for the average pianist because the right thumb in A has much more freedom of movement than the left thumb in B does, so in A the added note can hit with a bit more force, or tiny bit after/before the D#, to bring it out. Good pianists might make them identical.

One thing that makes it easier to sing (I hope) is the chord movements. Apart from the canon section, every time the chord changes, 2 parts stay on the same note, providing continuity and an anchor. This reflects the theme of the words - each part guides & follows the others!

It's an easy anthem intended for choirs just getting back to singing together post-pandemic - SATB, no divisi, easy ranges, no accidentals, and a section that's a 4-part canon. Score at https://t.co/eUZpcAFRUW - contact me for a copy, free for the duration of the pandemic.

@In_Purgatorio @ThreatNotation 2/3 would imply two triplet minims (each being 1/3 of a whole note) but the beat spacing here is 3 triplet quavers (which are each 1/12 of a whole note) in the first beat, 3 in the second, 2 in the last beat. 2/3 would imply 4 triplet quavers in each beat, 8/12 is correct.

@JoMarshComposer Yes - write the first note as a minim tied to a triplet crotchet, middle as two tied triplet minims, last as triplet crotchet tied to minim.

@JoMarshComposer To clarify: you can't get exact triplets by halving or dotting note values, it's mathematically impossible. You can get as close to it as you want but never exact - you can't add up quarters, sixteenths, etc and ever end up with exactly a third.

@JoMarshComposer It's as close as you can get without using tuples or smaller subdivisions in the top line. Technically the first note is 43/16 of a beat and is 1/48 of a crotchet longer than the triplet, but nobody except Ferneyhough would be likely to hear the difference or care.

@NoisyMV Sorry - was doing my best to basically say "don't read that one please" in a sensitive and understanding fashion while still explaining why! I meant the generic assumption of a debate, rather than your personal statement.

@NoisyMV I think my tweets below have summed it up better. You hopefully wouldn't bother reading a book about black rights by someone who your black friends told you was a racist. Don't read books about trans rights by someone your trans friends have said is transphobic.
@LucieWestenra @NoisyMV Oh yes. I think that might be where I involuntarily lifted it from, though other people have said the same thing in other ways. She's great.

@ScotNational @MxOolong Let's start a petition to call it a megapede instead

(yes, I know that isn't how the words work, it would just be funny)

@LucieWestenra @NoisyMV Absolutely. I'm glad to hear you're finding recognition and protection to be the default. I think we'll look back on the way transgender people are being treated now the way we look back now at the anti-gay screeds in the 1990s.

@NoisyMV It's more akin to reading a known-to-have-some-racist-views white person's book on whether black people should have rights. If I saw that someone who'd supported apartheid in SA had written about black rights, I wouldn't feel the need to read that to understand the debate.

@NoisyMV I mean, reading Stock to understand the transgender issue isn't *quite* as bad as reading Mein Kampf or the Protocols of the Elders of Zion to understand the anti-Semitism issue, but it's definitely heading in the same direction.

@NoisyMV It's what I've gathered of her views so far. She's superficially OK with social change and has token "trans friends" but seems implacably opposed to any legal change of gender, at least without surgery, and quite possibly to any access for AMAB people to women's spaces.

@NoisyMV ... basically this is like having a "debate" over whether depression should be treated or people should be left to just get over it, or whether racism should be allowed to continue or not. There are human lives at stake for one side, and the other side doesn't care if they die.

@NoisyMV Also Trans Like Me by C N Lester.

But I'm disturbed by the assumption there's a "debate" here. Stock's point of view is that transgender people should be forced to live as their birth genders, which we already know massively drives up suicide rates...
